Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in law by failing to consider the best interests of the child and whether there was a miscarriage of justice due to counsel incompetence
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.67(1)(c)
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found to have voluntarily abandoned Canada
Evidence_Type: Credible evidence of abandonment, allegations against counsel
Evaluation_Standard: Best interests of the child (inapplicable as child over 18)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Age of daughter (21 years old), voluntary abandonment of residency
Proceeding_Type: Appeal before IAD, followed by judicial review
Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider best interests of child, alleged incompetence of counsel
Review_Outcome: No error or miscarriage of justice found
Assessment_Standard: Substantial prejudice required for ineffective counsel claims
Evidence_Ignored: None found; key issues were addressed despite counsel allegations
Legal_Standard: Error of law, miscarriage of justice, procedural fairness
Application_Factor: Permanent resident status lost due to non-compliance with residency obligations
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed by IAD, judicial review denied
Decision_Review_Issue: Alleged legal error and procedural unfairness
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, correctness for questions of law
Cause_of_Refusal: Failure to meet residency requirements, H&C claim not established
Evidentiary_Issues: Credibility of applicants' intent to reside in Canada
Procedural_Fairness: Allegations of incompetent counsel reviewed; no substantial prejudice found
Credibility_Issues: Applicants' claimed ties to Canada vs. actual conduct indicating abandonment
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, argument that best interests of child were not considered
Procedural_Issue: Effectiveness of legal representation, adequacy of IAD's reasoning
Omission_Type: Failure to explicitly address best interests of adult child (deemed irrelevant)
